claim: The capital of France is Paris

supporting.text: Paris is officially designated as the capital of France in the French Constitution.

attacks.text: Paris is officially designated as the capital of France in the French Constitution.
Historical records show that Versailles briefly served as the capital during the reign of Louis XIV.
The brief relocation to Versailles was not constitutionally recognized and Paris remained the de jure capital.

supporting.text: The seat of the French government, including the President and Parliament, is located in Paris.

attacks.text: The seat of the French government, including the President and Parliament, is located in Paris.
The French government has occasionally held sessions in other cities, such as Versailles, for historical or ceremonial reasons.
These sessions outside Paris are exceptions and do not change the fact that Paris is the permanent and official seat of government.

supporting.text: Paris has been the political and administrative center of France since the Middle Ages.

attacks.text: Paris has been the political and administrative center of France since the Middle Ages.
During the Nazi occupation of France (1940-1944), the Vichy regime operated from Vichy, not Paris.
The Vichy regime was not internationally recognized as the legitimate government of France, and Paris remained the symbolic capital.
The capital was temporarily moved to Tours in 1940 during the German invasion.
These were emergency wartime relocations, not formal changes of capital status.

supporting.text: All major national institutions, such as the Supreme Court and central ministries, are headquartered in Paris.

attacks.text: All major national institutions, such as the Supreme Court and central ministries, are headquartered in Paris.
Some administrative functions and institutions are located in other cities, such as Lyon or Marseille.
The presence of major national institutions in Paris still solidifies its status as the capital, even if some functions are decentralized.
Historical capitals like Versailles have temporarily held the capital status, challenging the permanence of Paris as the capital.
Versailles was only the capital during specific historical periods, and Paris has been the consistent capital in modern times.
